prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife and kids.

First, the husband works from home part-time now. He chose the bedroom over the basement because of the view. The wife suggests the basement for less disruption. The husband's job is mostly conference calls, so the wife has to manage the kids and household tasks without disturbing him. She's struggling because she can't use the bathroom, shower, or do chores when he's on calls. She works from home too and handles most housework and kids. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom but did offer the basement. The husband says she's the asshole, but she thinks he's the one in the wrong for not using the basement.

So, the question is whether the author (wife) is wrong. Let's break it down. The husband has a choice between two locations. The basement is available and would minimize disruptions. By choosing the bedroom, he's causing issues for her. The wife is trying to manage the household and her job. She's given a logical solution (basement), but he's ignoring it for a better view. The husband's choice leads to her being unable to do her tasks. The wife isn't being disruptive on purpose; it's because of the kids and necessary chores. The husband's refusal to compromise might be the issue here.

In these kinds of situations, considering mutual respect and practicality is key. The husband's choice is self-serving (better view) at the expense of the wife's ability to function. The wife isn't in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed when he's in a shared space. The problem stems from his decision to set up in a space that's shared, leading to conflicts. Therefore, the husband's decision is the root of the problem, making the wife not at fault.
